comments.commentBody:
Thankfully, I am done with obamacare. I had it 2 years and never used it for fear of inflated billing and because I knew that even if I spent down my large deductible, the insurance would only pay half of my costs. In addition, I was forced to look for a doctor in the network. The older you get, the more exhausted you get hunting people and information down. Finally, healthcare.gov kept telling me, for two years, that I wasn't compliant, though they would never tell me why.

I feel sorry for those in the program given demands by health insurers--once again--to raise premiums by as much as 60%! Now the insured are in the position, when fines are at their highest, where they MUST pay for the insurance or be heavily fined for going without. THIS IS NOT FAIR. Many people have only choice of provider, and it's not fair to be forced to pay whatever they want or suffer a penalty. It's outrageous.

Insurance, in general is a gamble. You buy in advance and try to guess your needs. If you could pay as you go, you would always have the appropriate level of coverage. Clearly the system is designed to benefit the insurance companies rather than the consumers.

If the ACA is such a great achievement then why did our politicians in Washington opt themselves out it?  And how many people do you know who have had their hours cut and now work 2-3 part-time jobs now because the companies don't want to pay the insurance?  If you live outside the Beltway or on the Upper East Side, probably none.  But those of us in the real world know quite a few now "permanent part timers."

How about a public option for those states which did not expand Medicaid ... and, if possible, pay for the public option out of their share of federal funds they would otherwise receive?

That would satisfy my sense of order. No ... haven't looked at any law, only my sense of fairness. And, yes, I was not a fan of SCOTUS becoming a legislative re-drafter of the Affordable Care Act. That was one of those decisions which -- if you considered Chief Justice Roberts' description of the role he intended to play as Chief Justice as involving only calling "balls and strikes" -- I would definitely say "balls"!
More, more, more, more and more, Republican obstruction!
What happened to the idea of the Congress having the same health care options as the rest of the country? Maybe their vote would change.
The ACA could  be the start of something great if the GOP would participate in working to improve it. Instead they just keep voting to repeal it.

At the risk of sounding  like a broken record, the answer is: single payer. We already know how to do it. No need to tinker with a "too little too late" half measure like Obamacare. Medicare for all. We know it works. Ask anyone over 65 if they'd trade Medicare for any of the policies available. We don't need to beat out brains out about this or reinvent the wheel. This is a really easy one, folks. WHY can't Washington see that??

We can't get something better than the ACA until Americans vote more Democrats into Congress.  Republicans don't even believe in government and have done everything they could to make it look as if they have been working for the last 6 years, but in fact, they have done almost nothing in terms of legislation for the benefit of the nation.  If you enjoy useless,  vote for a Republican.
Obamacare may have helped many people but at the rate of insurance companies leaving the program, most notably United Healthcare, the largest insurer in the US, Obamacare is on life support.

First of all, illegal "immigrants" were specifically made ineligible for Obamacare coverage. Are they being counted as among the "uninsured"? If so, it was done on purpose.

Second, Obamacare distorted the cost of health insurance and raised it by mandating coverages for pre-existing conditions and substance/mental health treatment. If anyone is among the favored groups of poor and sick, the results have been favorable. But, for anyone healthy and making too much to qualify for a subsidy, the result has been much higher cost.

If you blow away the Obamacare smoke, the plan is a massive tax on the healthy/wealthy that is laundered through health insurers (that everyone hates) to benefit the sicker/poorer.

The young and healthy, who don't qualify for a subsidy, are not going to buy in to this because they are being asked to pay more than they can afford for more coverage than they need.

Obamacare is inexorably sliding toward a death spiral of adverse selection of the sickest/poorest in the country.

Those of us on the left all know that the only sane plan is, basically, Medicare for all. Generally speaking, Medicare is a well-run program that has done a very good job keeping costs down (one glaring exception: drug coverage). We obviously need the federal government as the negotiator/single payer.

Some people with good private medical insurance coverage will howl that the quality of care will decline with universal Medicare, and point to the public health system in the U.K. as an example. But the principle of the greatest good for the greatest number must control. (The wealthy will always be able to find "concierge" doctors for whatever ails them.)

As for the ACA, if that's the best we can do given raging Republican opposition to single-payer, of course we need a public option. But we all know what happened to that when the House and Senate bills were being formulated. Now, the public option has no chance of becoming law so long as the Republicans are in charge. Indeed, the Democrats would need a bullet-proof majority to get pretty much anything passed.

I just hope that if by some miracle the Democrats ever wind up with that bullet-proof majority, they don't make the nearly fatal mistake Obama did and try to get bipartisan support. That will never happen. If the Democrats had rammed through one of the better versions of the ACA in 2013 with zero Republican support, our country would have been much better off -- millions more insured and with lower prices.

When will Congress stop trying to sabotage health care reform, and start working for the American people to flatten and reverse health care costs?

The right-wing of the House wants to pass "Cross-State" purchase of coverage. Why don't they start there.

The truth is the right-wing House is more concerned with "getting even" over the ACS than helping working-class Americans. They demonstrate this by their record-setting streak of general inaction in the legislature.

Compared to the costs of the idiotic wars this country has and is waging in the middle east, the ACA is chump change. The only things politicians are upset about is the kick backs that they may not receive from the pharmaceuticals if things change that would affect the pharmaceuticals bottom line.

"History will almost surely..."

The reason surely needs to be modified the above statement is because any number of millions of Americans don't want Obamacare to become forced Medicaid for all.

And if you want to observe the future potential efficiency of the ACA, all you have to do is pay a visit to any State DMV office in NYC during business hours.

Most developed countries with universal health care (for example, UK, France, Canada) have a high cigarette tax exceeding $5 per pack to help fund the health care which is only fare since health care costs of smokers far exceeds those of non-smokers (the ACA allows for a 50% in premium for smokers but it generally does not seem to be used). The US cigarette tax remained at about $1.

So, in order to cover many high cost people who were previously uninsured, the insurance pools get more expensive than then were and thus people who already had insurance will see their rates rise. If you don't want those rates to rise or not as much, you must do as other countries do and increase the cigarette taxes.

If there is one major fix to the ACA, it should be to have the high cigarette taxes of other countries and put that money into health care.

Even before the ACA, 450,000 New Yorkers without insurance still had access to care through Federally Qualified Health Centers (FQHC)s. For example, on Manhattan's West Side is The Ryan Center and there is Urban Health Plan in the South Bronx.

Compared with our $3 trillion per year spent for health care costs, a very little is spent on FQHCs. Given the amount of health care delivered for so little money, it would be cost effective to spend at least 1% - 2% ($30 to $60 billion) on the FQHCs throughout the nation. This would be a way to ensure that nationwide, people without insurance still have access to health care.

had to start somewhere. The people who think it isn't needed are the ones that have either always had it or the means to pay for a doctor.

I grew up in a household with a single parent who never made more than $75 a week, Her parents before her had to pay for their children to go to school so many didn't. My Mom wasn't lazy; she worked hard cleaning houses and until she finally got a job as a housekeeper for a couple that fell in love with her, but she didn't have a car. But the couple she worked for were moving somewhere public transit didn't reach so she told them she couldn't work for them any longer and had to find another job. They bought the car, and they deducted from her $75 a week wages. We had no health care.

I'm 65 now with a comfortable living. I went to college part time at night and earned a degree. When i got a job that offered health and dental covearge I grabbed it. And both my kids and now my grandkids have health care and the opportunity to get a degree

If you've never had it, you don't know what it's like to go without or even what you're missing.

At its core, the ACA is a transfer of wealth from the rich to the poor and from the healthy to the sick.  Many agree with this, but those who disagree include a huge swath of the middle class who were largely bypassed.  The ACA was intended, for the most part, to help poor people, not the middle class.

If the GOP didn't savagely fight against the very idea of health care, more would be covered, and many more might have lived, but it was too busy giving away tax cuts to the 1% and funding the annual blank check to the Pentagon.

There is something very seedy about companies and individuals making huge profits at the expense of someone's health and survival.

The people who unwittingly oppose universal health care are morons. Since no one goes through life not needing health care, who would support a health care system that charges you double and puts your personal finances in jeopardy when you can't pay all your medical bills?

Most people cannot afford to pay out of pocket for health care and unless you are a member of Congress, health insurance won't cover everything. A trip to the emergency room and/or a night in the hospital will prove that soon enough to you. In most states, insurance companies won't cover "balance billing." If you are not familiar with balance billing, I advise you to check it out.

If you don't pay all your medical bills, your life will quickly become more complicated and a lot more expensive. A medical collection will stay on your credit report for years after you pay it off. Moving or changing jobs during this period may not be possible. And, any credit you can get, will be at rates and payments that are double what people with good credit have. Millions of people (presumably mostly conservatives) choose to go without insurance or sufficient insurance and are one accident or illness away from their life and their family's life being destroyed. These same people elect people who are more than happy to mess up their life for their personal aggrandizement.
"This can be done at a modest cost paid for by slightly higher taxes..." I seem to recall hearing that somewhere else before. The modest part always disappears.

I am one of those people that cannot afford healthcare. I am hoping to make it to 65 healthy but who knows. In the meantime, I just cannot afford paying $300 a month with a $6500 deductible, I just cannot. Wish me luck.

For those, because of income, that do not qualify for a subsidy, aca is simply an unaffordable catastrophic policy.  Family of 4--premium of $600 @ month with deductible of approximately $4500. That means no coverage until you incur $4500 in medical expenses which you are responsible for; while you're still paying $7200 a year in premiums?  Who would do this?

This article seems to overlook what is for me at least the most successful and important part of Obamacare, namely. that health insurance companies can no long refuse to cover you or charge you more just because you have a “pre-existing condition”.  This trumps all the other problems that can, in time, be rectified.

Let's take a look at the state of Iowa as an example of how ACA was received out in the field.

Previous to the introduction of ACA the health insurance market Blue Cross Blue Shield had over 80% of the market. BCBS decided NOT to participate in the healthcare market exchange, and now their plans are to begin in 2017, they say. United Healthcare entered the Iowa exchange market but with great reluctance and hesitation. Now they say that they will leave the exchange in 2017.

It has been apparent to many that United Healthcare did not want to see ACA succeed, in Iowa or anywhere. The largest healthcare company has an agenda against ACA, and they are using their clout to do so. They claim that they're losing money and ACA will just fail (they hope).

There was a healthcare co-op, CoOpportunity Health that started at the intro of ACA. Well, it turned out that the business for Coop Healthcare was too good for them. They were flooded with more applicants than they had predicted. They got the folks in the greatest need for remedial and immediate action. But they ran out of money, because they attracted too many people.

So now Iowa has ONE provider for ACA. Yes, they have to follow the ACA laws. But are they, Coventry Health, division of Aetna Insurance, committed to the health of ACA? No. These companies still wield too much power. They have an interest to see ACA fail. They are doing their damnedest to see, all hidden and behind the scenes, that ACA fails. Tell the whole story.
